Class org.codenarc.rule.unused.UnusedPrivateMethodRuleTest has 37 methods
Class org.codenarc.rule.unused.UnusedVariableRuleTest has 35 methods

rules.name: AbcMetric
rules.description: Checks the ABC size metric for methods/classes. A method (or "closure field") with an ABC score greater than the maxMethodAbcScore property (60) causes a violation. Likewise, a class that has an (average method) ABC score greater than the maxClassAverageMethodAbcScore property (60) causes a violation.

rules.name: AddEmptyString
rules.description: Finds empty string literals which are being added. This is an inefficient way to convert any type to a String.

rules.name: AssertWithinFinallyBlock
rules.description: Checks for assert statements within a finally block. An assert can throw an exception, hiding the original exception, if there is one.

rules.name: AssignCollectionSort
rules.description: The Collections.sort() method mutates the list and returns the list as a value. If you are assigning the result of sort() to a variable, then you probably don't realize that you're also modifying the original list as well. This is frequently the cause of subtle bugs.

rules.name: AssignCollectionUnique
rules.description: The Collections.unique() method mutates the list and returns the list as a value. If you are assigning the result of unique() to a variable, then you probably don't realize that you're also modifying the original list as well. This is frequently the cause of subtle bugs.

rules.name: AssignmentInConditional
rules.description: An assignment operator (=) was used in a conditional test. This is usually a typo, and the comparison operator (==) was intended.

rules.name: BigDecimalInstantiation
rules.description: Checks for calls to the BigDecimal constructors that take a double parameter, which may result in an unexpected BigDecimal value.

rules.name: BitwiseOperatorInConditional
rules.description: Checks for bitwise operations in conditionals, if you need to do a bitwise operation then it is best practice to extract a temp variable.

rules.name: BooleanGetBoolean
rules.description: This rule catches usages of java.lang.Boolean.getBoolean(String) which reads a boolean from the System properties. It is often mistakenly used to attempt to read user input or parse a String into a boolean. It is a poor piece of API to use; replace it with System.properties['prop'].

rules.name: BrokenNullCheck
rules.description: Looks for faulty checks for null that can cause a NullPointerException.

rules.name: BrokenOddnessCheck
rules.description: The code uses x % 2 == 1 to check to see if a value is odd, but this won't work for negative numbers (e.g., (-5) % 2 == -1). If this code is intending to check for oddness, consider using x & 1 == 1, or x % 2 != 0.

rules.name: ClassForName
rules.description: Using Class.forName(...) is a common way to add dynamic behavior to a system. However, using this method can cause resource leaks because the classes can be pinned in memory for long periods of time.

rules.name: ClassSize
rules.description: Checks if the size of a class exceeds the number of lines specified by the maxLines property (1000).

rules.name: ClosureAsLastMethodParameter
rules.description: If a method is called and the last parameter is an inline closure then it can be declared outside of the method call brackets.

rules.name: CollectAllIsDeprecated
rules.description: collectAll{} is deprecated since Groovy 1.8.1. Use collectNested instead{}.

rules.name: ComparisonOfTwoConstants
rules.description: Checks for expressions where a comparison operator or equals() or compareTo() is used to compare two constants to each other or two literals that contain only constant values, e.g.: 23 == 67, Boolean.FALSE != false, 0.17 <= 0.99, "abc" > "ddd", [a:1] <=> [a:2], [1,2].equals([3,4]) or [a:false, b:true].compareTo(['a':34.5, b:Boolean.TRUE], where x is a variable.

rules.name: ComparisonWithSelf
rules.description: Checks for expressions where a comparison operator or equals() or compareTo() is used to compare a variable to itself, e.g.: x == x, x != x, x <=> x, x < x, x >= x, x.equals(x) or x.compareTo(x), where x is a variable.

rules.name: ConfusingMultipleReturns
rules.description: Multiple return values can be used to set several variables at once. To use multiple return values, the left hand side of the assignment must be enclosed in parenthesis. If not, then you are not using multiple return values, you're only assigning the last element.

rules.name: ConsecutiveLiteralAppends
rules.description: Violations occur when method calls to append(Object) are chained together with literals as parameters. The chained calls can be joined into one invocation.

rules.name: ConsecutiveStringConcatenation
rules.description: Catches concatenation of two string literals on the same line. These can safely by joined.

rules.name: ConstantAssertExpression
rules.description: Checks for assert statements where the assert boolean condition expression is a constant or literal value.

rules.name: ConstantIfExpression
rules.description: Checks for if statements with a constant value for the if expression, such as true, false, null, or a literal constant value.

rules.name: ConstantTernaryExpression
rules.description: Checks for ternary expressions with a constant value for the boolean expression, such as true, false, null, or a literal constant value.

rules.name: CrapMetric
rules.description: Checks the CRAP (Change Risk Anti-Patterns) score for methods/classes. The CRAP metric score is based on the cyclomatic complexity and test coverage for individual methods. A method with a CRAP value greater than the maxMethodCrapScore property (30) causes a violation. Likewise, a class that has an (average method) CRAP value greater than the maxClassAverageMethodCrapScore property (30) causes a violation.

rules.name: CyclomaticComplexity
rules.description: Checks the cyclomatic complexity for methods/classes.A method (or "closure field") with a cyclomatic complexity value greater than the maxMethodComplexity property (20) causes a violation. Likewise, a class that has an (average method) cyclomatic complexityvalue greater than the maxClassAverageMethodComplexity property (20) causes a violation.

rules.name: DeadCode
rules.description: Dead code appears after a return statement or an exception is thrown. If code appears after one of these statements then it will never be executed and can be safely deleted.

rules.name: DoubleNegative
rules.description: There is no point in using a double negative, it is always positive. For instance !!x can always be simplified to x. And !(!x) can as well.

rules.name: DuplicateCaseStatement
rules.description: Check for duplicate case statements in a switch block, such as two equal integers or strings.

rules.name: DuplicateImport
rules.description: Duplicate import statements are unnecessary.

rules.name: DuplicateMapKey
rules.description: A map literal is created with duplicated key. The map entry will be overwritten.

rules.name: DuplicateSetValue
rules.description: A Set literal is created with duplicate constant value. A set cannot contain two elements with the same value.

rules.name: EmptyCatchBlock
rules.description: In most cases, exceptions should not be caught and ignored (swallowed).

rules.name: EmptyClass
rules.description: Reports classes without methods, fields or properties. Why would you need a class like this?

rules.name: EmptyElseBlock
rules.description: Empty else blocks are confusing and serve no purpose.

rules.name: EmptyFinallyBlock
rules.description: Empty finally blocks are confusing and serve no purpose.

rules.name: EmptyForStatement
rules.description: Empty for statements are confusing and serve no purpose.

rules.name: EmptyIfStatement
rules.description: Empty if statements are confusing and serve no purpose.

rules.name: EmptyInstanceInitializer
rules.description: An empty class instance initializer was found. It is safe to remove it.

rules.name: EmptyMethod
rules.description: A method was found without an implementation. If the method is overriding or implementing a parent method, then mark it with the @Override annotation.

rules.name: EmptyStaticInitializer
rules.description: An empty static initializer was found. It is safe to remove it.

rules.name: EmptySwitchStatement
rules.description: Empty switch statements are confusing and serve no purpose.

rules.name: EmptySynchronizedStatement
rules.description: Empty synchronized statements are confusing and serve no purpose.

rules.name: EmptyTryBlock
rules.description: Empty try blocks are confusing and serve no purpose.

rules.name: EmptyWhileStatement
rules.description: Empty while statements are confusing and serve no purpose.

rules.name: EqualsAndHashCode
rules.description: If either the equals(Object) or the hashCode() methods are overridden within a class, then both must be overridden.

rules.name: EqualsOverloaded
rules.description: The class has an equals method, but the parameter of the method is not of type Object. It is not overriding equals but instead overloading it.

rules.name: ExplicitArrayListInstantiation
rules.description: This rule checks for the explicit instantiation of a ArrayList using the no-arg constructor. In Groovy, it is best to write "new ArrayList()" as "[]", which creates the same object.

rules.name: ExplicitCallToAndMethod
rules.description: This rule detects when the and(Object) method is called directly in code instead of using the & operator. A groovier way to express this: a.and(b) is this: a & b

rules.name: ExplicitCallToCompareToMethod
rules.description: This rule detects when the compareTo(Object) method is called directly in code instead of using the <=>, >, >=, <, and <= operators. A groovier way to express this: a.compareTo(b) is this: a <=> b, or using the other operators.

rules.name: ExplicitCallToDivMethod
rules.description: This rule detects when the div(Object) method is called directly in code instead of using the / operator. A groovier way to express this: a.div(b) is this: a / b

rules.name: ExplicitCallToEqualsMethod
rules.description: This rule detects when the equals(Object) method is called directly in code instead of using the == or != operator. A groovier way to express this: a.equals(b) is this: a == b and a groovier way to express : !a.equals(b) is : a != b

rules.name: ExplicitCallToGetAtMethod
rules.description: This rule detects when the getAt(Object) method is called directly in code instead of using the [] index operator. A groovier way to express this: a.getAt(b) is this: a[b]

rules.name: ExplicitCallToLeftShiftMethod
rules.description: This rule detects when the leftShift(Object) method is called directly in code instead of using the << operator. A groovier way to express this: a.leftShift(b) is this: a << b

rules.name: ExplicitCallToMinusMethod
rules.description: This rule detects when the minus(Object) method is called directly in code instead of using the - operator. A groovier way to express this: a.minus(b) is this: a - b

rules.name: ExplicitCallToModMethod
rules.description: This rule detects when the mod(Object) method is called directly in code instead of using the % operator. A groovier way to express this: a.mod(b) is this: a % b

rules.name: ExplicitCallToMultiplyMethod
rules.description: This rule detects when the minus(Object) method is called directly in code instead of using the * operator. A groovier way to express this: a.multiply(b) is this: a * b

rules.name: ExplicitCallToOrMethod
rules.description: This rule detects when the or(Object) method is called directly in code instead of using the | operator. A groovier way to express this: a.or(b) is this: a | b

rules.name: ExplicitCallToPlusMethod
rules.description: This rule detects when the plus(Object) method is called directly in code instead of using the + operator. A groovier way to express this: a.plus(b) is this: a + b

rules.name: ExplicitCallToPowerMethod
rules.description: This rule detects when the power(Object) method is called directly in code instead of using the ** operator. A groovier way to express this: a.power(b) is this: a ** b

rules.name: ExplicitCallToPutAtMethod
rules.description: Detects when the putAt(Object, Object) method is called directly in code instead of using the [] index operator. A groovier way to express this: map.putAt(k, v) is this: map[k] = v.

rules.name: ExplicitCallToRightShiftMethod
rules.description: This rule detects when the rightShift(Object) method is called directly in code instead of using the >> operator. A groovier way to express this: a.rightShift(b) is this: a >> b

rules.name: ExplicitCallToXorMethod
rules.description: This rule detects when the xor(Object) method is called directly in code instead of using the ^ operator. A groovier way to express this: a.xor(b) is this: a ^ b

rules.name: ExplicitGarbageCollection
rules.description: Calls to System.gc(), Runtime.getRuntime().gc(), and System.runFinalization() are not advised. Code should have the same behavior whether the garbage collection is disabled using the option -Xdisableexplicitgc or not. Moreover, "modern" jvms do a very good job handling garbage collections. If memory usage issues unrelated to memory leaks develop within an application, it should be dealt with JVM options rather than within the code itself.

rules.name: ExplicitHashMapInstantiation
rules.description: This rule checks for the explicit instantiation of a HashMap using the no-arg constructor. In Groovy, it is best to write "new HashMap()" as "[:]", which creates the same object.

rules.name: ExplicitHashSetInstantiation
rules.description: This rule checks for the explicit instantiation of a HashSet using the no-arg constructor. In Groovy, it is best to write "new HashSet()" as "[] as Set", which creates the same object.

rules.name: ExplicitLinkedHashMapInstantiation
rules.description: This rule checks for the explicit instantiation of a LinkedHashMap using the no-arg constructor. In Groovy, it is best to write "new LinkedHashMap()" as "[:]", which creates the same object.

rules.name: ExplicitLinkedListInstantiation
rules.description: This rule checks for the explicit instantiation of a LinkedList using the no-arg constructor. In Groovy, it is best to write "new LinkedList()" as "[] as Queue", which creates the same object.

rules.name: ExplicitStackInstantiation
rules.description: This rule checks for the explicit instantiation of a Stack using the no-arg constructor. In Groovy, it is best to write "new Stack()" as "[] as Stack", which creates the same object.

rules.name: ExplicitTreeSetInstantiation
rules.description: This rule checks for the explicit instantiation of a TreeSet using the no-arg constructor. In Groovy, it is best to write "new TreeSet()" as "[] as SortedSet", which creates the same object.

rules.name: ForLoopShouldBeWhileLoop
rules.description: A for loop without an init and update statement can be simplified to a while loop.

rules.name: GStringAsMapKey
rules.description: A GString should not be used as a map key since its hashcode is not guaranteed to be stable. Consider calling key.toString().

rules.name: GStringExpressionWithinString
rules.description: Check for regular (single quote) strings containing a GString-type expression (${...}).

rules.name: GetterMethodCouldBeProperty
rules.description: If a class defines a public method that follows the Java getter notation, and returns a constant, then it is cleaner to provide a Groovy property for the value rather than a Groovy method.

rules.name: GroovyLangImmutable
rules.description: The groovy.lang.Immutable annotation has been deprecated and replaced by groovy.transform.Immutable. Do not use the Immutable in groovy.lang.

rules.name: HardCodedWindowsFileSeparator
rules.description: This rule finds usages of a Windows file separator within the constructor call of a File object. It is better to use the Unix file separator or use the File.separator constant.

rules.name: HardCodedWindowsRootDirectory
rules.description: This rule find cases where a File object is constructed with a windows-based path. This is not portable, and using the File.listRoots() method is a better alternative.

rules.name: ImportFromSamePackage
rules.description: An import of a class that is within the same package is unnecessary.

rules.name: ImportFromSunPackages
rules.description: Avoid importing anything from the 'sun.*' packages. These packages are not portable and are likely to change.

rules.name: IntegerGetInteger
rules.description: This rule catches usages of java.lang.Integer.getInteger(String, ...) which reads an Integer from the System properties. It is often mistakenly used to attempt to read user input or parse a String into an Integer. It is a poor piece of API to use; replace it with System.properties['prop'].

rules.name: MethodCount
rules.description: A class with too many methods is probably a good suspect for refactoring, in order to reduce its complexity and find a way to have more fine grained objects. The maxMethods property (30) specifies the threshold.

rules.name: MethodSize
rules.description: Checks if the size of a method exceeds the number of lines specified by the maxLines property (100).

rules.name: MisorderedStaticImports
rules.description: Static imports should never be declared after nonstatic imports.

rules.name: MultipleUnaryOperators
rules.description: Checks for multiple consecutive unary operators. These are confusing, and are likely typos and bugs.

rules.name: NestedBlockDepth
rules.description: Checks for blocks or closures nested more than maxNestedBlockDepth (5) levels deep.

rules.name: NoWildcardImports
rules.description: Wildcard imports, static or otherwise, should not be used.

rules.name: ParameterAssignmentInFilterClosure
rules.description: An assignment operator was used on a parameter in a filtering closure. This is usually a typo, and the comparison operator (==) was intended.

rules.name: ParameterCount
rules.description: Checks if the number of parameters in method/constructor exceeds the number of parameters specified by the maxParameters property.

rules.name: RandomDoubleCoercedToZero
rules.description: The Math.random() method returns a double result greater than or equal to 0.0 and less than 1.0. If you coerce this result into an Integer or int, then it is coerced to zero. Casting the result to int, or assigning it to an int field is probably a bug.

rules.name: RemoveAllOnSelf
rules.description: Don't use removeAll to clear a collection. If you want to remove all elements from a collection c, use c.clear, not c.removeAll(c). Calling c.removeAll(c) to clear a collection is less clear, susceptible to errors from typos, less efficient and for some collections, might throw a ConcurrentModificationException.

rules.name: ReturnFromFinallyBlock
rules.description: Returning from a finally block is confusing and can hide the original exception.

rules.name: ThrowExceptionFromFinallyBlock
rules.description: Throwing an exception from a finally block is confusing and can hide the original exception.

rules.name: UnnecessaryBigDecimalInstantiation
rules.description: It is unnecessary to instantiate BigDecimal objects. Instead just use the decimal literal or the 'G' identifier to force the type, such as 123.45 or 123.45G.

rules.name: UnnecessaryBigIntegerInstantiation
rules.description: It is unnecessary to instantiate BigInteger objects. Instead just use the literal with the 'G' identifier to force the type, such as 8G or 42G.

rules.name: UnnecessaryBooleanExpression
rules.description: Checks for unnecessary boolean expressions, including ANDing (&&) or ORing (||) with true, false, null, or a Map/List/String/Number literal. Also checks for negation (!) of true, false, null, or a Map/List/String/Number literal.

rules.name: UnnecessaryBooleanInstantiation
rules.description: Use Boolean.valueOf() for variable values or Boolean.TRUE and Boolean.FALSE for constant values instead of calling the Boolean() constructor directly or calling Boolean.valueOf(true) or Boolean.valueOf(false).

rules.name: UnnecessaryCallForLastElement
rules.description: This rule checks for excessively verbose methods of accessing the last element of an array or list. For instance, it is possible to access the last element of an array by performing array[array.length - 1], in Groovy it is simpler to either call array.last() or array[-1]. The same is true for lists. This violation is triggered whenever a get, getAt, or array-style access is used with an object size check.

rules.name: UnnecessaryCallToSubstring
rules.description: Calling String.substring(0) always returns the original string. This code is meaningless.

rules.name: UnnecessaryCast
rules.description: Checks for unnecessary cast operations

rules.name: UnnecessaryCatchBlock
rules.description: Violations are triggered when a catch block does nothing but throw the original exception. In this scenario there is usually no need for a catch block, just let the exception be thrown from the original code. This condition frequently occurs when catching an exception for debugging purposes but then forgetting to take the catch statement out.

rules.name: UnnecessaryCollectCall
rules.description: Some method calls to Object.collect(Closure) can be replaced with the spread operator. For instance, list.collect { it.multiply(2) } can be replaced by list*.multiply(2). Warning: if a collection is null, collect will return an empty list, while *. will return null.

rules.name: UnnecessaryCollectionCall
rules.description: Useless call to collections. This call doesn't make sense. For any collection c, calling c.containsAll(c) should always be true, and c.retainAll(c) should have no effect.

rules.name: UnnecessaryConstructor
rules.description: This rule detects when a constructor is not necessary; i.e., when there's only one constructor, it's public, has an empty body, and takes no arguments.

rules.name: UnnecessaryDefInFieldDeclaration
rules.description: If a field has a visibility modifier or a type declaration, then the def keyword is unneeded. For instance, 'static def constraints = {}' is redundant and can be simplified to 'static constraints = {}.

rules.name: UnnecessaryDefInMethodDeclaration
rules.description: If a method has a visibility modifier or a type declaration, then the def keyword is unneeded. For instance 'def private method() {}' is redundant and can be simplified to 'private method() {}'.

rules.name: UnnecessaryDefInVariableDeclaration
rules.description: If a variable has a visibility modifier or a type declaration, then the def keyword is unneeded. For instance 'def private n = 2' is redundant and can be simplified to 'private n = 2'.

rules.name: UnnecessaryDotClass
rules.description: To make a reference to a class, it is unnecessary to specify the '.class' identifier. For instance String.class can be shortened to String.

rules.name: UnnecessaryDoubleInstantiation
rules.description: It is unnecessary to instantiate Double objects. Instead just use the double literal or the 'D' identifier to force the type, such as 123.45d or 0.42d.

rules.name: UnnecessaryElseStatement
rules.description: When an if statement block ends with a return statement the else is unnecessary. The logic in the else branch can be run without being in a new scope.

rules.name: UnnecessaryFinalOnPrivateMethod
rules.description: A private method is marked final. Private methods cannot be overridden, so marking it final is unnecessary.

rules.name: UnnecessaryFloatInstantiation
rules.description: It is unnecessary to instantiate Float objects. Instead just use the float literal with the 'F' identifier to force the type, such as 123.45F or 0.42f.

rules.name: UnnecessaryGString
rules.description: String objects should be created with single quotes, and GString objects created with double quotes. Creating normal String objects with double quotes is confusing to readers.

rules.name: UnnecessaryGroovyImport
rules.description: A Groovy file does not need to include an import for classes from java.lang, java.util, java.io, java.net, groovy.lang and groovy.util, as well as the classes java.math.BigDecimal and java.math.BigInteger.

rules.name: UnnecessaryIfStatement
rules.description: Checks for if statements where the if and else blocks (or subsequent fall-through to a return), are merely returning true and false constants. These cases can be replaced by a simple return statement.

rules.name: UnnecessaryInstanceOfCheck
rules.description: This rule finds instanceof checks that cannot possibly evaluate to true. For instance, checking that (!variable instanceof String) will never be true because the result of a not expression is always a boolean.

rules.name: UnnecessaryInstantiationToGetClass
rules.description: Avoid instantiating an object just to call getClass() on it; use the .class public member instead.

rules.name: UnnecessaryIntegerInstantiation
rules.description: It is unnecessary to instantiate Integer objects. Instead just use the literal with the 'I' identifier to force the type, such as 8I or 42i.

rules.name: UnnecessaryLongInstantiation
rules.description: It is unnecessary to instantiate Long objects. Instead just use the literal with the 'L' identifier to force the type, such as 8L or 42L.

rules.name: UnnecessaryModOne
rules.description: Any expression mod 1 (exp % 1) is guaranteed to always return zero. This code is probably an error, and should be either (exp & 1) or (exp % 2).

rules.name: UnnecessaryNullCheck
rules.description: Groovy contains the safe dereference operator, which can be used in boolean conditional statements to safely replace explicit "x == null" tests.

rules.name: UnnecessaryNullCheckBeforeInstanceOf
rules.description: There is no need to check for null before an instanceof; the instanceof keyword returns false when given a null argument.

rules.name: UnnecessaryObjectReferences
rules.description: Violations are triggered when an excessive set of consecutive statements all reference the same variable. This can be made more readable by using a with or identity block.

rules.name: UnnecessaryOverridingMethod
rules.description: The overriding method merely calls the same method defined in a superclass

rules.name: UnnecessaryPackageReference
rules.description: Checks for explicit package reference for classes that Groovy imports by default, such as java.lang.String, java.util.Map and groovy.lang.Closure.

rules.name: UnnecessaryParenthesesForMethodCallWithClosure
rules.description: If a method is called and the only parameter to that method is an inline closure then the parentheses of the method call can be omitted.

rules.name: UnnecessaryPublicModifier
rules.description: The 'public' modifier is not required on methods or classes.

rules.name: UnnecessaryReturnKeyword
rules.description: In Groovy, the return keyword is often optional. If a statement is the last line in a method or closure then you do not need to have the return keyword.

rules.name: UnnecessarySafeNavigationOperator
rules.description: Check for the safe navigation operator (?.) applied to constants and literals, which can never be null.

rules.name: UnnecessarySelfAssignment
rules.description: Method contains a pointless self-assignment to a variable or property.

rules.name: UnnecessarySemicolon
rules.description: Semicolons as line terminators are not required in Groovy: remove them. Do not use a semicolon as a replacement for empty braces on for and while loops; this is a confusing practice.

rules.name: UnnecessarySetter
rules.description: Checks for explicit calls to setter methods which can, for the most part, be replaced by assignment to property. A setter is defined as a method call that matches set[A-Z] but not set[A-Z][A-Z] such as setURL(). Setters take one method argument.

rules.name: UnnecessaryStringInstantiation
rules.description: Use a String literal (e.g., "...") instead of calling the corresponding String constructor (new String("..")) directly.

rules.name: UnnecessarySubstring
rules.description: This rule finds usages of String.substring(int) and String.substring(int, int) that can be replaced by use of the subscript operator. For instance, var.substring(5) can be replaced with var[5..-1].

rules.name: UnnecessaryTernaryExpression
rules.description: Checks for ternary expressions where the conditional expression always evaluates to a boolean and the true and false expressions are merely returning true and false constants. Also checks for ternary expressions where both expressions are the same constant or variable.

rules.name: UnnecessaryToString
rules.description: Checks for unnecessary calls to toString().

rules.name: UnnecessaryTransientModifier
rules.description: The field is marked as transient, but the class isn't Serializable, so marking it as transient has no effect.

rules.name: UnusedImport
rules.description: Imports for a class that is never referenced within the source file is unnecessary.

rules.name: UseCollectMany
rules.description: In many case collectMany() yields the same result as collect{}.flatten(). It is easier to understand and more clearly conveys the intent.

rules.name: UseCollectNested
rules.description: Instead of nested collect{}-calls use collectNested{}
